messages.content: What is introverted intuition?

Introverted intuition - Ni - is your ability to see your own future path. It's laser-focused on what you want, where you're going, your goals. Think sniper rifle, not shotgun. While extroverted sensing feeds you information about what's happening right now, Ni takes that data and locks onto the best single path forward. It's the function that makes you see it through no matter what. Future-oriented. Goal-driven. Relentless.
How does Ni work with Se?

Ni and Se are on an axis - they work together. Se is extroverted sensing - it gathers data about the present moment, what's physically happening around you right now. That information feeds directly into Ni, which processes it and generates insight about your future path. Se brings the raw material. Ni refines it into direction. You can't have one without the other on the cognitive stack.
Which types have Ni hero?

INTJ and INFJ. That's it. Ni hero means you lead with future vision - you're constantly focused on where you're going and what you want. Your entire life revolves around optimizing the best path forward. You bounce back from setbacks better than anyone because your future focus pulls you through anything. INFJs can survive brutal health crises. INTJs zero in on goals like nothing else exists.
What's the difference between Ni and Si?

Ni is future-oriented. Si is past-oriented. Si asks "what was" - it's about duty, memory, experience, faith in what's already happened. Ni asks "what will be" - it's about desire, intention, goals, where you're headed. Si anchors you to the past. Ni propels you toward the future. Si is duty-based. Ni is want-based. Completely different directions in time.
Why is Ni called the luck function?

Because Ni users have this uncanny ability to avoid disaster and find the right path forward. The higher Ni is in your stack - especially hero or child - the more luck you have. An ISTP child with Ni child can walk through a minefield and somehow not get blown up. It's not random chance. It's the intuitive sense of which path to take, which choice to make. Ni sees the future and guides you away from danger without you even knowing why.
What is Ni parent?

Ni parent is the second function for ENTJ and ENFJ. It makes you responsible with your goals and desires. You're the mentor who knows where you're going and helps others find their direction too. You don't get stuck overanalyzing - you pick a path and commit. Ni parent gives you the maturity to be goal-oriented without being reckless about it. You're focused but also wise about the future you're building.
Which types have Ni child?

ISTP and ISFP. Ni child is the third function - it's innocent, pure, almost magical. These types have luck built in because their Ni child is uncorrupted. They want what they want without shame or overthinking. An ISTP or ISFP just knows which direction feels right, and they follow it with childlike certainty. That innocence protects them. It's why they can take risks that would destroy other types and come out fine.
What does Ni inferior look like?

Ni inferior is the fourth function for ESTP and ESFP. It makes you insecure about what you want. You know you desire something, but you're terrified to commit to it. So you get stuck gathering more and more information, hoping clarity will just appear. It won't. This creates failure to launch syndrome - you can't make decisions because you're paralyzed by fear of choosing wrong. ESPs need someone with Se child to help them feel safe making a choice.
How is Ni like a sniper rifle?

Ni locks onto one target - your goal - and stays zeroed in on it. It's precise. Focused. Singular. You're not exploring ten different possibilities like Ne does. You're not scattering your energy. You find the best path forward and you commit everything to that one direction. Sniper rifle versus shotgun. Ne is the shotgun - hits everything, explores all options. Ni is the sniper - one shot, one target, relentless focus until you hit it.
What types use Ni?

Eight types total. Ni hero: INTJ, INFJ. Ni parent: ENTJ, ENFJ. Ni child: ISTP, ISFP. Ni inferior: ESTP, ESFP. Half the types have Ni somewhere in their ego function stack. These are your future-focused, goal-driven, see-it-through types. They value freedom and independence because Ni demands the ability to choose your own path forward.
Why do Ni users need freedom?

Because Ni is all about choosing your own path forward. If you restrict an Ni user's freedom, you're directly attacking their core function. They have to be able to decide what they want and move toward it. Cage them and they'll hate you - or they'll find a way out anyway. This is especially true for types with high Se like all the SPs and NJs. Give them choices. Let them pick their direction. Force them and you've made an enemy.
How should you parent an Ni user child?

Give them choices. Always. Even if both options lead to the same result. "Do you want to go to bed now or in five minutes?" Either way they're going to bed, but you gave them the power to choose. That's what matters. Ni users need to feel like they're steering their own future. Take that away and you damage them. Si users? You can just tell them when bedtime is. But Ni users will fight you if you don't give them agency over their own path.
What's the difference between Ni and Ne?

Ni is one path forward. Ne is all paths forward. Ni is introverted - it's about your own future, your goals, your desires. Ne is extroverted - it's about everyone's possibilities, exploring every option simultaneously. Ni is fire - concentrated, intense, focused. Ne is water - flowing everywhere, enveloping everything. Ni commits to the best path. Ne wants to see what all the paths look like before deciding. Completely different approaches to the future.
Why can INFJs bounce back from illness?

Ni hero. INFJs have this incredible ability to recover from devastating health crises because their Ni hero keeps them locked onto survival and future goals. They can survive meningitis, undergo experimental surgeries, bounce back from things that would kill other types. It's not physical resilience - Se inferior means they're actually physically vulnerable. It's mental and spiritual resilience. Their future focus pulls them through when their body wants to quit.
What does it mean that Ni is movement-oriented?

Ni isn't static. It's constantly moving you toward your goal. It's not about sitting around dreaming of the future - it's about progressing step by step toward what you want. You're always in motion, always adjusting your path to stay on target. Ni doesn't explore for the sake of exploring. Every movement has purpose. You're walking a straight line to your destination, and everything you do is about getting closer to that endpoint.
How do you help an ESTP with Ni inferior?

Pair them with someone who has Se child - like an ESTJ or ESFJ. These types are focused on giving people what they want. They'll present the ESTP with options and reasons why each path makes sense. That external validation and structure helps the ESTP feel safe enough to actually make a decision. ESPs get paralyzed by their own Ni inferior insecurity. Someone with strong Se can show them it's okay to commit to a direction and just go for it.
What are Chart the Course types?

Chart the Course types are the interaction style that includes three of the four Ni users in their ego. They're called See It Through types because once they set a goal, they don't stop until they reach it. These are people who pick a destination and stay locked on it no matter what obstacles appear. Ni is the core of this interaction style - that future focus and relentless commitment to the path forward defines how they approach everything.
Why is Ni described as fiery?

Because Ni is concentrated, intense, focused energy aimed at one point - just like fire. It burns through obstacles to reach the goal. Intuitive types in general are fiery compared to grounded sensor types. But specifically, Ni is precise fire - a laser beam, a welding torch. It's not the spreading flames of Ne. It's focused heat that cuts through everything between you and what you want. That intensity, that singular focus - that's the fire of Ni.
What happens if you tell an Ni user what to do?

They'll resent you and find a way around it anyway. Ni users need to choose their own path forward. If you try to force them onto your path, you're attacking the core of who they are. Even Ni inferior types like ESPs will eventually push back - it just takes them longer to gather the courage. But Ni hero and parent types? They'll hate you immediately and either leave or undermine you. You can't control someone whose entire existence is about choosing their own future direction.
How does failure to launch syndrome affect ESPs?

ESPs have Ni inferior - they're insecure about what they want. So they get stuck in analysis paralysis. They gather information endlessly, hoping they'll suddenly feel certain about which path to take. They won't. The more data they collect, the more paralyzed they become. They want to launch, but fear of choosing wrong keeps them frozen. This is why ESPs need external support from Se child types who can validate their choices and give them permission to just pick something and commit.
